If you have any questions, the Professor will be in Ingersoll Hall Extension 431 (our regular classroom) on Monday at 6:00 PM, even though you are not required to come because there is no lecture. You could come if you have any question. Good luck!

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Good Evening, Guys! I wanted to thank every one of you for your amazing work for this class project. Your user interfaces look awesome! You could begin uploading your HTML, CSS, JavaScript and image files into the repository into the Raw Templates folder (cisc3140-su19-project/Front-End Team Weekly Writeups/Raw Templates/). You do not have to add the Jinja code into your templates - once they are all there, I will replace the relevant code with Jinja code, and upload everything into a new folder (probably it will be called templates) for the use of the Back-End team.

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Here s a link to some nice Flask documentation that shows various ways in which a python file can send data into a template - by using a single function call: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.0.x/api/#template-rendering   There is no limit for the number of variables, or type of variables, that are sent into the function. This gives full freedom to the Back-End team in choosing what to send. Perhaps ideally for the Back-End team, they could send a whole JSON array of a kind (say, posts or ports, etc.) within one argument: posts = posts. Then, inside the HTML (not in Python), there will be Jinja2 code that will read the array. For instance, there could be Jinja2 code such as {{ posts[0]['content'] }} that would access the data within the first index of the array, and then find the value of the key 'content' and display it. I hope, guys, that this explanation is somewhat helpful. Please let me know if something is unclear! Thank you so so much!

name: Miriam Briskman
text: The Back-End team will not do Jinja2 - we do so. The Back-End team could, for example, use the popular function render_template, which is written in python and has 2 types of arguments: (1) the HTML template into which the info will be sent, and (2) various variables will information to fill in the template. This is just the name of the function; the Front-End team will render the template with Jinja2 inside HTML. I did this exact thing in Assignment 1, and it worked pretty well. I will show you the files that I created for that assignment in class (remind me, please, if I forget).

name: Mg
text: @Miriam Briskman absolutely! Let me know if you/your team would like to go over some of the points etc

name: Mg
text: Well, you all can use python and jinja2 if you see it fit, but it might not be necessary. I don’t see how the work would flow then, unless you did all your request and responses in python to us instead of JS, but JS has tools(like I mentioned, query selector and so on, that make front end development very nice). It’s up to you all, let me know if that makes sense. If we (the backend) did jinja2 we’d rendering VIEWS, which wouldn’t make sense, unless you wrote very complicated JS to keep track of the elements on the HTML to change style and pages based on user action. Right?

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Thank you very much, @Mg . That's a very quality report! We'll speak about this in class.

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Yes, @Johnny Lee . This will allow us to eliminate the usage of JavaScript for transmitting information.

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Good Afternoon, Mark. I uploaded 2 PDF files into the 'master' branch of the repository. One of them, named "To the Database Team - Data Needed for Class Project", contains the names of all the tables and keys within these tables that will be in the database. The other one, called "To the Back-End Team - Possible Tasks", contains the tasks that the python files the Back-End team builds should accomplish. There will be some additional missions, which will become more evident once the Product team finishes building all the wireframes. Because the tasks currently written in the file are considered the 'core' stuff that the website should do, it might be worth to begin working on them. In today's group work, we could clarify all the issues that we have so far to continue working on the project. Thank you!

name: Miriam Briskman
text: The parts that will connect to the code built by the Back-End team are, probably, going to be the news posts and the sorting menu. The Python code of the Back-End team could pass a 2-dimensional array of news into the HTML template (the rows are the individual news and the columns are the aspects of each news post, like (1) content (2) day/month/year and time of publication (3) title of the post (4) number of upvotes (5) number of downvotes.) Inside HTML, we could refer to the individual entries inside pairs of braces {{ }} by writing {{ arr[0]['content'] }}, which represents the content of the oldest news post. Therefore, it would be sufficient for the Back-End team to pass us 'arr' itself through the 'render_template' function, without even accessing its entries. The Front-End team, with your permission, could begin by dividing the 6 tasks among us and tackling them. Guys, what do you think about this idea? We could begin working on this on Monday if you see it appropriate.

name: Miriam Briskman
text: Hey, Guys! The Product team has finished designing the first wireframe (as they showed in class.) They shared it with us via Google Slides. This "Homepage" wireframe consists of 6 main areas: (1) Logo image (2) Sort dropdown input at the top-right corner (3) Search box (of content on the homepage) (4) Vertical menu (in its closed mode) on the left that opens up by clicking the hamburger menu button (5) Vertical menu (in its open mode) (6) the news posts themselves that appear at the center of the page.
